page.title: 14LOCAL HISTORY-TAMAR BRIDGE
page.content: AS LONG AGO AS 1924, INCREASING TRAFFIC LED TO AN AGITATION FOR THE REPLACEMENT OF THE FERRIES BY A ROAD BRIDGE.REPORTS WERE OBTAINED FROM ENGINEERS IN 1929 AND 1930,AND ALTHOUGH NO FURTHER ACTION WAS TAKEN AT THE TIME, A ROAD BRIDGE ACROSS THE {TAMAR}REMAINED A FEATURE OF PLANNING SCHEMES AND PROPOSALS.THE GREAT INCREASE IN TRAFFIC AFTER THE WAR LED TO INCREASING CONGESTION AT THE FERRIES,PARTICULARLY IN THE SUMMER MONTHS.THE LOCAL AUTHORITIES BECAME INCREASINGLY CONCERNED ABOUT THE MATTER AND THE BRIDGE WAS FINALLY BUILT IN 1961 BY CORNWALL COUNTY COUNCIL AND PLYMOUTH CITY COUNCIL.IT WAS OPENED BY{THE QUEEN MOTHER}AND IN 1962 IT WAS FOUR SHILLINGS AND SIX PENCE TO CROSS IN A CAR.IT IS 1848 FEET LONG AND WHEN IT WAS FIRST BUILT IT WAS THE LONGEST IN THE COUNTRY.
